SENT.plain: A 68-year-old man was referred to our hospital for a dysphagia evolving for 10 days
Clinical examination had found neurological signs as contralateral Horner's syndrome, ipsilateral palatal paresis, gait ataxia and hoarseness
Video-fluoroscopy showed a lack of passage of contrast medium to the distal esophagus
The cranial MRI had shown an acute ischemic stroke in the left lateral medullar region and the diagnosis of Wallenberg syndrome (WS) was established
WS remains an unknown cause of dysphagia in the clinical practice of the gastroenterologist
